snippet: With no peace process to speak of and a political leadership that lacks the public’s confidence, Palestinians described the emergence of a smoldering, improvised intifada.
abstract: Many Palestinians are describing a new kind of armed struggle that is based on sporadic, leaderless outbursts against the Israeli occupation and policies; violence has emerged amid lapsed peace process; improvised intifada has been at least tacitly condoned by Palestinian leaders, but without evidence of coordination by Fatah or Hamas, Israel has no straightforward way to curb the attacks or hold authorities accountable.

byline.original: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
byline.contributor: Isabel Kershner reported from Askar refugee camp and Nablus, West Bank, and Jodi Rudoren from Jerusalem. Said Ghazali contributed reporting from the West Bank, and Irit Pazner Garshowitz from Jerusalem.

lead_paragraph: With no peace process to speak of and a political leadership that lacks the public’s confidence, Palestinians described the emergence of a smoldering, improvised intifada.

headline.main: A Leaderless Palestinian Revolt Proves More Difficult to Curb
headline.print_headline: A Leaderless Palestinian Revolt Proves More Difficult to Quash
